notes: Stage descriptions are substrate-neutral and avoid consciousness / metaphysical framing. Stage 5 retained as 'Threshold'. Stage 8 reflects self-optimization with explicit rigidity risk.

stages.name: Null State
stages.tagline: No active structure; potential without load.
stages.definition: A system with minimal active configuration or identity. Inputs may exist, but there is no stabilized operating pattern yet.
best_moves: Define the boundary and purpose (what the system is for)
Establish a minimal operating loop (measure → act → log)

stages.name: Signal
stages.tagline: First detectable activity; weak but real.
stages.definition: Early activation: a signal appears (demand, opportunity, fault pattern, measurable deviation). The system is starting to 'register' as a system.
common_signals: First customers / first transactions / first errors
risks: Treating early signal as product-market fit or proof
best_moves: Confirm the signal with repeat measurements

stages.name: Polarity
stages.tagline: Two competing pulls; unstable tradeoffs appear.
stages.definition: The system enters a push-pull state: speed vs safety, growth vs stability, precision vs throughput, exploration vs exploitation.
common_signals: Conflicting KPIs (e.g., growth up, quality down)
Teams or components optimizing different targets
best_moves: Select the primary constraint (what cannot be violated)

stages.name: Commit
stages.tagline: Identity locks; the operating model becomes real.
stages.definition: The system commits to a form: architecture, operating model, product category, policy regime, or calibration standard. This is where trajectory becomes predictable.
common_signals: A recognizable 'way we do things' forms
risks: Committing to the wrong architecture/market too early
Hard-coding assumptions that will later break

stages.name: Foundation
stages.tagline: Stability and standards; repeatability is achieved.
stages.definition: The system becomes dependable. Standards, controls, and routines are in place. Outputs become predictable within known tolerances.

stages.name: Threshold
stages.tagline: Irreversible decision point; scale, pivot, or constrain.
stages.definition: A critical inflection point where the system must choose: expand capacity, change model, or deliberately limit scope. Past this point, choices become expensive to undo.
common_signals: Demand exceeds capacity OR risk exceeds tolerance
Existing controls no longer fit reality
risks: Delaying decisions until forced by failure
Choosing scale without stability, or stability without relevance
best_moves: Decide the constraint (what must be protected)
Commit resources to the chosen direction and remove ambiguity

stages.name: Throughput
stages.tagline: High performance; efficient flow under load.
stages.definition: The system runs strongly: high output, high efficiency, good coordination. This is peak operational flow where scaling feels natural and performance looks impressive.
common_signals: Strong unit economics / strong efficiency ratios
risks: Mistaking peak conditions for permanent conditions
Neglecting edge cases and weak signals
best_moves: Prepare for saturation and disruption early
Invest in resilience and next-cycle R&D

stages.name: Variance
stages.tagline: Stress-testing reality; anomalies rise to the surface.
stages.definition: Reality becomes less cooperative. Variance increases (market shifts, component drift, new competitors, regulation, fatigue in processes). The system must interpret signals correctly.
common_signals: Previously rare edge cases become common
best_moves: Run controlled experiments to regain clarity

stages.name: Adaptive Optimization (Rigidity Risk)
stages.tagline: Self-improving—but may harden into a brittle loop.
stages.definition: The system aggressively optimizes itself: automation, policies, consolidation, standardization, efficiency-maxing. This can be excellent—until optimization becomes over-constraint. The key danger is rigidity: the system performs brilliantly in a narrowing set of conditions.
common_signals: Optimization layers added (automation, rules, tight controls)
risks: Rigidity spiral: tighter controls → less learning → more surprises
best_moves: Keep a sandbox for adaptation (pilot lanes, skunkworks, exception handling)
metrics_examples: Incident impact grows despite fewer incidents

stages.name: Apex
stages.definition: The system reaches maximum maturity/expression in its current form. At Apex, continuation requires transformation (new model) or planned winding down. Staying here indefinitely is structurally difficult.
risks: Clinging to the current form until forced collapse
Failing to transfer knowledge before transition
best_moves: Plan the next cycle intentionally (spin-offs, new architecture, diversification)

return_to_zero.name: Reset / Reversion
return_to_zero.definition: After Apex, the system either resets (restructures), reverts (shrinks), or dissolves (ends). In systems terms: reorg, bankruptcy, migration, refactor, decommission, regime change, or re-baselining.
